questions.text: A patient comes with palpitation to ER. His Pulse-180/min and BP-70mm of Hg systolic. ECG shows narrow QRS complex tachycardia with regular heart rate. What is the next step in management? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) DC cardioversion

 

For a patient presenting with hemodynamically unstable symptoms such as a significantly low blood pressure and a high heart rate, as indicated by a pulse of 180/min and systolic BP of 70 mmHg, immediate DC cardioversion is indicated. This procedure is critical for restoring normal heart rhythm and preventing further cardiovascular compromise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Valsalva Maneuver: it is typically used in stable patients to attempt cardioversion of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) back to a normal rhythm. It is not suitable for patients showing signs of hemodynamic instability.

 

Option C. Adenosine: it is effective in terminating certain types of SVT by temporarily blocking the AV node but is used in stable patients. Given the patient's low BP, this is not the first-line approach.

 

Option D. Verapamil: it is a calcium channel blocker used for rate control in cases of SVT, more appropriate for stable patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DC cardioversion is the emergency treatment of choice for a patient with hemodynamically unstable narrow QRS complex tachycardia, as it quickly restores normal rhythm and stabilizes the patient.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Cardiology/SVT/chap 246

choices.text: Screening tests define risk of passing genetic disorder
Screening tests are more accurate than diagnostic tests

questions.text: A genetic counsellor is discussing various types of genetic tests with a couple planning for a child. Which of the following statements accurately describes genetic screening? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Screening tests define risk of passing genetic disorder

 

Genetic screening/testing

 

  • Genetic testing is a type of medical test that identifies changes in genes, chromosomes, or proteins. 
  • It is a process to analyse blood or skin for the systematic search for persons with a particular genotype in a defined population (usually invasive procedures)
  • In order to locate this faulty gene, scientists search for variations in larger pieces of DNA called "markers", latter are found nearby the DNA and become the basis of genetic screening
  • The results of a genetic test can confirm or rule out a suspected genetic condition or help determine a person's chance of developing or passing on a genetic. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Screening tests are more accurate than diagnostic tests: Incorrect. Screening tests assess risk and are not as definitive as diagnostic tests, which provide a precise diagnosis.

 

Option C. Screening requires genetic mapping: Incorrect. Genetic screening does not necessarily involve genetic mapping, which is a detailed analysis of the entire genome.

 

Option D. Involve invasive procedures: Incorrect. Screening tests can often be performed using non-invasive methods such as blood or saliva samples, although some genetic tests may require invasive procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Genetic screening tests are used to define the risk of passing on a genetic disorder and can help determine the likelihood of developing a genetic condition.
  • They are not as definitive as diagnostic tests and do not necessarily involve invasive procedures or genetic mapping.

choices.text: Sensory level is from T10 to L1
Uterine contractility is mediated by innervations from level T7 - T8
In the 1st stage of labor, pain is due to the fibers at level of T10 - L1
In early labor, pain is usually because of the uterine contraction

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding innervation of the uterus? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Uterine contractility is mediated by innervations from level T7 - T8

 

Explanation:

 

The incorrect statement regarding the innervation of the uterus is option B. Uterine contractility is primarily mediated by hormonal mechanisms rather than by specific spinal innervations. Hormones such as estrogen, prostaglandins, and oxytocin play a significant role in inducing uterine contractions, while progesterone helps maintain uterine relaxation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sensory level is from T10 to L1: The sensory innervation of the uterus is indeed from spinal levels T10 to L1. These afferent fibers enter the spinal cord via the inferior hypogastric plexus and are responsible for transmitting sensory information from the uterus.

 

Option C. In the 1st stage of labor, pain is due to the fibers at level of T10 - L1: During the 1st stage of labor, pain is mediated by spinal segments T10 to L1. This pain is due to the distension of the cervix and lower uterine segment, as well as the contraction of the uterus.

 

Option D. In early labor, pain is usually because of the uterine contraction: In early labor, pain is usually related to uterine contractions, which stimulate nociceptors in the genital tract and can cause discomfort and pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uterine contractility is not mediated by innervations from spinal level T7 - T8; instead, it is primarily influenced by hormonal mechanisms.

 

 

Ref: Page 500, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

choices.text: B and C
A and B
A, B, C

questions.text:
Which of the following drug reduces mortality in COVID-19 patients? (INICET Nov 2020)

A. Dexamethasone

B. Remdesivir

C. Favipiravir
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Only A

 

  • In severe COVID-19 infection, there is a systemic inflammatory response, which can lead to lung injury and multiple organ dysfunction. Corticosteroids, due to their anti-inflammatory effect, can help mitigate these negative effects and reduce the mortality in patients.
  • Only dexamethasone has been shown to reduce mortality in severe covid19 cases.
  • Dexamethasone 6 mg IV/PO once daily for 10 days or until hospital discharge is given in severe cases. In the absence of dexamethasone, equivalent doses of other corticosteroids such as prednisone, methylprednisone, or hydrocortisone may be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Remdesivir

 

  • Mechanism: Remdesivir is an antiviral drug that inhibits viral RNA polymerase.
  • Usage: It is used to reduce the duration of illness in COVID-19 patients, but it has not been conclusively shown to reduce mortality.

 

Option C. Favipiravir

 

  • Mechanism: Favipiravir is an antiviral drug that inhibits viral RNA polymerase.
  • Usage: It is used in some countries for the treatment of COVID-19, but there is no strong evidence to support a reduction in mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dexamethasone is the only drug among the listed options that has been shown to reduce mortality in severe COVID-19 cases, due to its potent anti-inflammatory effects. Remdesivir and favipiravir have not demonstrated a mortality benefit.

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition given in the graph? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Non-competitive

 

The above given graph is showing non-competitive inhibition.

 

When the substrate and the inhibitor are chemically not similar and have different shapes, the inhibitor binds away from the active site, i.e., at the allosteric site. This type of inhibition is known as non-competitive inhibition.

 

In this curve, the Km is constant but the Vmax has decreased.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Competitive: In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor resembles the substrate and competes for binding to the active site. This increases the apparent Km (the affinity of the enzyme for the substrate decreases), but Vmax remains unchanged. The Lineweaver-Burk plot would show a change in slope and the same Y-intercept.

 

Option B. Uncompetitive: In uncompetitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, preventing the complex from releasing products. This decreases both Km and Vmax. The Lineweaver-Burk plot would show parallel lines (same slope) with different Y-intercepts.

 

Option D. Allosteric: Allosteric inhibition involves inhibitors binding to an allosteric site, which can cause non-competitive inhibition if it changes the enzyme's conformation. However, the specific graph in the question fits the description of non-competitive inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given graph illustrates non-competitive inhibition, where the inhibitor binds to an allosteric site, causing a decrease in Vmax while Km remains constant. This type of inhibition affects the enzyme's activity without altering the substrate's binding affinity.

choices.text: Epithelial cells covered by bacteria
Gardenella vaginalis with Bacillin rods
Doderlein bacili in the macrophage

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes in with a grayish-white vaginal discharge. Upon conducting a gram stain of the discharge, clue cells are observed. What are clue cells? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epithelial cells covered by bacteria

 

Clue cells are epithelial cells that are covered by bacteria, which gives them a distinctive appearance. In the context of bacterial vaginosis, these cells appear with a fuzzy or irregular border due to the presence of small gram-negative bacilli adhering to their surface. The presence of clue cells is a hallmark of bacterial vaginosis, a condition caused by an imbalance in the normal vaginal flora.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Degranulated neutrophils: Degranulated neutrophils are not clue cells. Neutrophils are involved in the immune response, and their degranulation refers to the release of granules that contain enzymes and other substances. They do not have the fuzzy appearance characteristic of clue cells.

 

Option C. Gardenella vaginalis with Bacillin rods: Gardenella vaginalis is a bacterium associated with bacterial vaginosis, but clue cells are not specifically Gardenella vaginalis with Bacillin rods. Clue cells are epithelial cells covered by various types of bacteria, not a specific bacterium or rod-shaped bacteria.

 

Option D. Doderlein bacilli in the macrophage: Doderlein bacilli (lactobacilli) are normally present in the vagina and help maintain a healthy environment. They are not found within macrophages, nor are they related to the appearance of clue cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clue cells are epithelial cells covered by bacteria, and their presence is indicative of bacterial vaginosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented in OPD with a swelling in his neck. Given below is the histopathological image. What is the likely diagnosis?  (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Medullary carcinoma of thyroid

 

The histopathological image shows Amyloid deposition and nests of polygonal cells, which is suggestive of medullary carcinoma of thyroid. This type of cancer is associated with the presence of amyloid deposits, which can be seen as pinkish extracellular material in the histological sections. These amyloid deposits are derived from calcitonin produced by the neoplastic C-cells (parafollicular cells).

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is a neuroendocrine tumor that arises from the parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland, which produce calcitonin. The histopathological hallmark of MTC is the presence of amyloid stroma, often stained with Congo red, showing apple-green birefringence under polarized light. Additionally, the tumor cells are often arranged in nests or sheets, with polygonal or spindle-shaped cells.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid: Characterized by the formation of papillae and distinct nuclear features like Orphan-Annie eye nuclei, nuclear grooves, and pseudoinclusions. It typically does not have amyloid deposition.

 

Option C. Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid: Typically shows follicles filled with colloid, and Hurthle cells may be present. This type is also known for hematogenous spread rather than lymphatic spread.

 

Option D. Anaplastic carcinoma of the thyroid: A highly aggressive form of thyroid cancer, characterized by pleomorphic giant cells, spindle cells, and a lack of differentiated features seen in other thyroid carcinomas. It also lacks the amyloid deposits seen in medullary carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following STD is transmitted by all components of the blood?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Syphilis

 

Syphilis is a sexually transmitted disease (STD) caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. It can be transmitted through various means, including sexual contact, from mother to child during childbirth, and through blood transfusions. Syphilis can be transmitted by all components of the blood, making it a comprehensive risk in blood transfusion contexts.

 

While other infections like hepatitis B and C, malaria, and HIV can also be transmitted through blood transfusions, the question specifically asks for an STD. Among the options given, syphilis is the only STD that fits this criterion.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis: Incorrect because while hepatitis B and C can be transmitted through blood transfusions, they are not classified primarily as sexually transmitted diseases.

 

Option B. Filariasis: Incorrect because filariasis is a parasitic disease transmitted by mosquitoes, not through blood transfusions or as an STD.

 

Option C. Malaria: Incorrect because malaria is a parasitic infection transmitted by mosquitoes and through blood transfusions, but it is not an STD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, is an STD that can be transmitted by all components of the blood, highlighting the importance of thorough blood screening.

choices.text: Calcium channel blocker

questions.text: For the diagnosis of resistant hypertension, the patient should have uncontrolled hypertension despite taking three antihypertensive drugs. This should include at least one? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diuretic

 

Resistant hypertension is defined as blood pressure that remains above the target levels despite the use of three antihypertensive agents of different classes, one of which should be a diuretic. This is because diuretics, typically thiazide diuretics, help to reduce blood volume and are effective in lowering blood pressure. Including a diuretic ensures optimal blood pressure control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium channel blockers: Calcium channel blockers are used but are not specifically required for the diagnosis of resistant hypertension.

 

Option B. Beta blockers: Beta blockers are also commonly used but not specifically required for the definition.

 

Option C. Alpha blockers: Alpha blockers may be used as part of the treatment regimen but are not specifically required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnostic criteria for resistant hypertension include having blood pressure above target despite taking three drugs, one of which must be a diuretic, OR having controlled blood pressure with four or more drugs. Typically, a thiazide diuretic is used in the setting of hypertension.

questions.text: Eicosanoids are formed from:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arachidonic acid

 

Eicosanoids are derived from arachidonic acid, which is a polyunsaturated fatty acid found in cell membranes. Arachidonic acid serves as the precursor for eicosanoid synthesis when it is released from membrane phospholipids through the action of enzymes such as phospholipase A2. Once released, arachidonic acid can be metabolized into various eicosanoids, including prostaglandins, leukotrienes, and thromboxanes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Platelet aggregation: Platelet aggregation refers to the process of blood platelets clumping together. While eicosanoids can influence platelet aggregation by promoting or inhibiting it, they are not formed directly from platelet aggregation. Platelet aggregation involves the activation of platelets and the release of various signaling molecules, including some eicosanoids, as part of the clotting process.

 

Option C. 4 fused rings: Eicosanoids are not characterized by having four fused rings. Instead, they are typically small molecules with a 20-carbon backbone structure.

 

Option D. Arginine: Arginine is an amino acid and is not directly involved in the formation of eicosanoids. Eicosanoids are primarily derived from arachidonic acid, as mentioned earlier.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eicosanoids are bioactive lipid molecules that play a crucial role in various physiological processes in the body. They are formed from arachidonic acid. Arachidonic acid has (20 C, 4=) and is synthesized from linoleic acid. Eicosanoids (Prostaglandins and leukotrienes) are synthesized from arachidonic acid. So, Linoleic acid is considered as most essential fatty acid.

 

Reference: Harperâ€™s 31st ed/pg- 224

questions.text: A patient was treated for peptic ulcer with an H. pylori regimen. Which of the following is used to assess the success of treatment? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Urea breath test

 

The urea breath test is the preferred non-invasive method to assess the success of H. pylori eradication therapy. It works by detecting the presence of urease, an enzyme produced by H. pylori. During the test, the patient ingests a urea solution labeled with a carbon isotope. If H. pylori is present, the urease enzyme breaks down the urea, releasing labeled carbon dioxide, which is then measured in the patient's breath. This test is highly accurate, non-invasive, and convenient for follow-up, making it the best choice for confirming the eradication of H. pylori after treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endoscopy: While endoscopy with a biopsy for a rapid urease test can be used to detect H. pylori, it is invasive and not ideal for follow-up assessments when less invasive options are available.

 

Option B. IgG antibody study: This test detects antibodies against H. pylori but is not useful for follow-up after treatment. Antibody levels can remain elevated for a long time even after the infection has been eradicated, leading to false-positive results.

 

Option D. Urease test of biopsy: This method, similar to endoscopy, involves an invasive procedure to obtain a gastric tissue sample for a rapid urease test. Although accurate, it is not preferred for follow-up due to its invasiveness compared to non-invasive options like the urea breath test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The urea breath test is the preferred non-invasive method for assessing the success of H. pylori eradication therapy due to its accuracy and convenience.

questions.text: Match the following? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

 

  • Malaria (A-4, Giemsa stain): Giemsa's solution is a mixture of methylene blue, eosin, and Azure B. It is used to stain blood smears for the identification of malarial parasites. Giemsa's stain is regarded as the world's standard diagnostic technique for malaria's plasmodium, and it is also the basic stain for classifying lymphomas in the Kiel classification.
  • Tuberculosis (B-1, ZN stain): The Ziehl-Neelsen method uses a carbol fuchsin stain, acid alcohol decolorizer, and methylene blue counterstain. Acid-fast organisms, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, stain red, while the background of debris stains blue. The ZN stain confirms the acid-fast property of mycobacteria.
  • Leprosy (C-2, Fite Faraco stain): Fite-Faraco stain is the routinely used method to demonstrate Mycobacterium leprae in tissue sections. It is more sensitive than the ZN method in the detection of Mycobacterium leprae in tissue sections. The leprosy bacillus is much less acid and alcohol fast than the tubercle bacillus, therefore alcohol is removed from the hydrating and dehydrating steps and 10% sulphuric acid is used as a decolorizer in place of acid/alcohol solution.

 

Mycobacterial cell walls contain a waxy substance composed of mycolic acids. These are ÃŸ-hydroxy carboxylic acids with chain lengths of up to 90 carbon atoms. The property of acid fastness is related to the carbon chain length of the mycolic acid found in any particular species.

 

  • Actinomycosis (D-3, Gram stain): Actinomyces species are gram-positive bacteria, and the Gram stain is used to visualize them. Actinomyces appear as filamentous, branching, gram-positive rods when stained with the Gram stain. Gram stain is more sensitive for the diagnosis of actinomycosis than culture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each infectious disease has a specific staining technique for identification: Malaria (Giemsa stain), Tuberculosis (ZN stain), Leprosy (Fite Faraco stain), and Actinomycosis (Gram stain).

questions.text: Which of the following drugs in leprosy treatment cause hyperpigmentation? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clofazimine

 

Explanation:

 

  • Clofazimine is an antimicrobial agent used primarily in the treatment of leprosy.
  • One of the notable side effects of clofazimine is skin pigmentation changes, which can manifest as hyperpigmentation.
  • This occurs because clofazimine accumulates in the skin, leading to discoloration.
  • The pigmentation typically appears as a reddish or brownish coloration and can be distressing for patients due to its noticeable cosmetic impact.
  • The pigmentation is long-lasting and may take several months to years to fade after discontinuation of the drug.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dapsone: Dapsone is another drug used in the treatment of leprosy, but it does not cause hyperpigmentation. Its side effects include hemolysis and methemoglobinemia, especially in individuals with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.

 

Option B. Ofloxacin: Ofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic used to treat various bacterial infections, including leprosy, but it is not associated with hyperpigmentation. Its common side effects include gastrointestinal disturbances and tendonitis.

 

Option C. Rifampicin: Rifampicin is an antibiotic used to treat several bacterial infections, including leprosy. It can cause reddish-orange discoloration of bodily fluids like urine, sweat, and tears but does not cause hyperpigmentation of the skin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clofazimine is a drug used in leprosy treatment that can cause significant and long-lasting hyperpigmentation of the skin.

questions.text: Identify the surgical instrument shown in the image: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mixter forceps

 

Mixter forceps is used to clamp the blood vessels and prevent blood loss and pass ligatures and dissect pedicles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adson's forceps: Adson's forceps are used in surgery to manipulate soft tissues such as fascia and skin during suturing.

 

 

Option B. Kocher's forceps: Kocher's forceps is used to clamp the blood vessels and prevent blood loss. It has 2 x 1 teeth at the tip.

 

 

Option D. Rampley forceps: Rampley forceps are used in general surgery to hold swabs and sponges or to grasp tissue. It has a fenestrated tip.

questions.text:
Organize the subsequent structures in the auditory pathway, beginning from the receptors and moving towards the cortex: (INICET May 2023)

 

  1. Auditory Cortex
  2. Spiral ganglion
  3. Cochlear Nucleus
  4. Lateral leminiscus
  5. Inferior colliculus
  6. Olivary complex
  7. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2-3-6-4-5-7-1

 

The correct sequence of structures in the auditory pathway, beginning from the receptors (cochlea) and moving towards the auditory cortex, is as follows:

 

2. Spiral ganglion: The auditory nerve fibers originate here.

 

3. Cochlear Nucleus: The auditory nerve fibers synapse in the cochlear nuclei located in the brainstem.

 

6. Olivary complex: After the cochlear nucleus, the pathway proceeds to the superior olivary complex.

 

4. Lateral lemniscus: From the superior olivary complex, the auditory signals travel via the lateral lemniscus.

 

5. Inferior colliculus: The lateral lemniscus projects to the inferior colliculus in the midbrain.

 

7. Medial geniculate body: The signals are then relayed to the medial geniculate body of the thalamus.

 

1. Auditory Cortex: Finally, the signals reach the auditory cortex (Area 41) in the temporal lobe for processing.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

AUDITORY PATHWAY

 

E â€“ Eighth nerve

 

C â€“ Cochlear nucleus

 

O â€“ Olivary complex (superior)

 

L â€“ Lateral lemniscus

 

I â€“ Inferior colliculus

 

M â€“ Medial geniculate body

 

A â€“ Auditory cortex

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with symptoms of confusion, thirst, and abdominal pain. On examination, she had pallor and thoracic spine tenderness. X-ray spine showed osteolytic lesions. Her lab investigations showed the following findings: Hb - 6.9g/dL, WBC 4000/cm3 with normal differential count, Serum calcium 13mg/dL, Creatinine 2.3mg/dL, Total protein 9g/dL, Albumin 2.4g/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Multiple myeloma

 

The patient's symptoms, combined with lab findings of anemia, hypercalcemia, elevated total protein, and low albumin, along with osteolytic lesions, are indicative of multiple myeloma. The CRAB criteria (hyperCalcemia, Renal failure, Anemia, and Bone lesions) support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:


 

Option A. Metastatic breast cancer can present similarly but usually has a different primary site.

 

Option C. Primary hyperparathyroidism causes hypercalcemia but not the full CRAB criteria.

 

Option D. Milk Alkali Syndrome causes hypercalcemia and renal impairment but not the protein abnormalities or osteolytic lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiple myeloma is characterized by anemia, hypercalcemia, renal failure, and bone lesions.

choices.text: Hospitalize for anti-venom administration and immobilization

questions.text: Which of these steps is included in the management of snake bite?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hospitalize for anti-venom administration and immobilization

 

Management of snake bite:

 

 

Immobilization is done to minimize the spread of the venom. Hospitalization, followed by AS administration is the definitive management of snake bites.

 

Measures that can be taken in the case of snakebite:

 

  • Apply firm pressure over the bitten area, which delays the absorption of venom
  • Pressure immobilization is recommended for elapid and sea-snake bites, but not for viper bites as it may cause local necrosis
  • Immediately apply a broad firm bandage (Sutherland wrap on the bitten area and around the limb. As much of the limb should be bandaged as possible. It should be tight enough to occlude the superficial venous and lymphatic return, but not the arterial or deep venous flow. A pressure of 50 to 70 mm Hg is maintained.
  • In bites on the trunk, head, or neck, apply firm pressure over the bitten area
  • Immobilize the limb, as movement can accelerate the spread of venom
  • Make the patient lie on one side in the recovery position so that the airway is clear, in case of vomiting or fainting.

 

Measures contraindicated in the case of snakebite:

 

  • Suction and incision of the wound
  • Electric shock treatment of wound site
  • Application of tourniquets because they obstruct arterial flow and cause ischemia
  • Ice water immersion of the bitten limb
  • Do not attempt to kill or catch the snake as it may be dangerous.
  • Administration of AS locally at the wound site.
  • Herbal/local remedies

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Loose Tourniquet: Not recommended as it can cause ischemia and increase the risk of complications.

 

Option B. Debridement: Not advisable as it can exacerbate the spread of venom.

 

Option C. Killing the Snake: Attempting to kill or catch the snake can be dangerous and is not necessary for treatment.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The management of snake bites primarily involves hospitalization for the administration of anti-venom and immobilization of the affected limb to minimize the spread of venom.

questions.text:
Organize the subsequent afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle, proceeding from the medial to the lateral direction. (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1. General somatic

2. General visceral

3. Special somatic

4. Special visceral
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2, 4, 1, 3

 

The question is regarding afferent columns hence we will only look at the afferent columns to arrange these options and not the whole arrangement of all the columns in the diagram.

 

The afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle can be categorized from medial to lateral into four types: general visceral, special visceral, general somatic, and special somatic.

 

 

 

The subsequent afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle can be organized from medial to lateral as follows:

 

2. General visceral: The general visceral column carries sensory information from the internal organs, such as the visceral sensations of hunger, fullness, and discomfort.

 

4. Special visceral: This column includes sensory input related to the special senses of taste and hearing. The special visceral sensory column carries information from the taste buds and the cochlea (auditory part of the ear).

 

1. General somatic: The general somatic column carries sensory information related to touch, temperature, pain, and pressure from the body's skin and musculoskeletal system.

 

3. Special somatic: This column contains sensory input related to the special senses of vision, equilibrium, and proprioception (awareness of body position). It includes input from the eyes, ears (for balance), and proprioceptors in muscles and joints.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the floor of the fourth ventricle, the arrangement of the afferent sensory columns from medial to lateral is - 2. General visceral, 4. Special visceral, 1. General somatic & 3. Special somatic

questions.text: A 10-year-old child was operated for a tumour in the lower end of femur. The gross specimen of the resected tumour is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INCET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteosarcoma

 

OSTEOSARCOMA

 

  • The matrix forming the tumor is the cause of calcification.
  • It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone behind multiple myeloma.
  • The classic form of osteosarcoma is typically seen in patients in their second or third decade, with a peak in the adolescent growth spurt.
  • It occurs more frequently in males than in females and is found in the metaphyseal areas of long bones, with 50% of lesions about the knee joint.
  • The distal femur is the most common site, followed by the proximal tibia and then the proximal humerus.
  • Characteristic histological feature is malignant cells with osteoid formation. This osteoid matrix presents as calcification.
  • Osteosarcoma is the most common radiation-induced sarcoma.
  • Clinical features:
    • Almost all patients report progressive pain. Night pain may be an important clue to the true diagnosis, seen in 25% of patients
       
  • Radiological Features:
    • Permeated lytic destruction of metaphyseal bone, with eventual cortical breakthrough into the subperiosteal space and subsequent formation of a Codman triangle at the diaphyseal end of the tumor.

 

 

Codmanâ€™s triangle

 

  • As the tumor continues to push its way into the extracortical soft tissue, a typical sunburst pattern of neoplastic bone may be seen outside the involved bone.

 

 

  • MRI is the best test to measure the extent of the tumor within the bone and in the soft tissue and to determine the relationship of the tumor to nearby anatomical structures.
  • A bone scan should be obtained to look for skeletal metastases, and radiographs and CT scans of the chest should be done to search for pulmonary metastases; the lungs are the most common sites of metastases.
  • CT scan may be helpful in differentiating osteosarcoma from myositis ossificans or an osteochondroma. The ossification in myositis ossificans is more mature at the periphery of the lesion, whereas the center of osteosarcoma is more heavily ossified.
  • Treatment:
    • It is highly radio-resistant tumor and ideally, treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.
    • With the combination of chemotherapy and surgical treatment, the prognosis for 5-year survival is 70-80%.
    • The drugs commonly used today include high-dose methotrexate, doxorubicin, cisplatin, and ifosfamide.
    • In osteosarcoma of the extremities, limb-sparing surgery with wide resection of the tumor is the standard approach.
    • Amputation is reserved for the exceptional or recurrent case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chondrosarcoma. It occurs over a broad age range, with peaks between 40 and 60 years for primary chondrosarcoma and between 25 and 45 years for secondary chondrosarcoma. Most common in Proximal location like pelvis (most common site), proximal femur, and proximal humerus. Most common malignant tumor of bone in hand (although rarely occur). Secondary chondrosarcomas arise at the site of a pre-existing benign cartilage lesion like in case of multiple enchondromas and multiple hereditary exostoses. Chondrosarcoma can produce hyperglycemia in 85% cases. Metastasis from Chondrosarcoma most commonly goes to lungs (hematogenous). The radiographic appearance is similar to enchondroma, it is a lesion arising in the medullary cavity with irregular matrix calcification. The pattern of Calcification is described as â€œPunctateâ€, â€œpopcornâ€, or â€œcomma-shapedâ€. It has a more aggressive appearance with Bone destruction, cortical erosions, periosteal reaction, and rarely a soft-tissue mass. Treatment is by Wide local excision/Radical excision.

 

 

Option C. GCT. They typically occur in patients 20-40 years old, and there is a slight female predominance. The most common location for this tumor is the distal femur, followed closely by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise. GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation. Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients. Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT. Radiographic findings often are diagnostic. The lesions are eccentrically located in the epiphyses of long bones and usually about the subchondral bone with soap bubble appearance. Microscopically, giant cell tumors are composed of many multinucleated giant cells (typically 40-60 nuclei per cell) in a sea of mononuclear stromal cells (malignant cells). Curettage and stripping of the cavity is the treatment of choice.

 

 

Option D. Chondroblastoma. Chondroblastoma is a rare type of benign tumor that grows at the ends of the long bones, close to the joints. Most often, the tumors develop at the ends of the femur, tibia, or humerus. They typically occur in children and young adults, and are more common in males. Although chondroblastomas are not cancerous, they can continue to grow if left untreated. A growing tumor can destroy the surrounding bone, making it painful to move the nearby joint. The cause of chondroblastomas is not known. The tumors are thought to arise from the growth plates at the ends of the bones, near joints. Classic â€œchicken wireâ€ calcification is seen. Epiphysis + calcification + upper end humerus = Chondroblastoma.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows a cut section of osteosarcoma of the femur.
  • The destructive tumor arises from the metaphysis, with extensive involvement of the marrow cavity and extension into soft tissue.

questions.text: A female presented with loss of pain and temperature, but her touch sensation was intact. Imaging showed cavitation around the central canal. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans.  D) Syringomyelia

 

Syringomyelia is characterized by the presence of a fluid-filled cavity or syrinx within the spinal cord, which typically expands over time. This condition most commonly affects the cervical and thoracic regions of the spinal cord. The classic presentation includes a loss of pain and temperature sensation in a "cape-like" distribution over the shoulders and back, while touch, vibration, and proprioception (posterior column sensations) remain intact. This pattern of sensory loss is due to the disruption of the decussating (crossing) fibers of the spinothalamic tract, which carry pain and temperature sensations. The cavitation around the central canal of the spinal cord is a hallmark of syringomyelia and leads to the aforementioned symptoms.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Brown-Sequard syndrome: This condition results from hemisection or damage to one half of the spinal cord. It typically presents with ipsilateral motor loss and loss of proprioception and vibration sense, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the level of the lesion. This does not match the described symptoms and imaging findings.

 

Option B. Tabes dorsalis: This is a late manifestation of neurosyphilis, characterized by degeneration of the dorsal columns of the spinal cord, leading to impaired proprioception and vibration sense, ataxia, and lightning pains. It does not cause cavitation around the central canal or the specific dissociated sensory loss seen in this patient.

 

Option C. Syringobulbia: This is a similar condition to syringomyelia but involves the brainstem (medulla oblongata) rather than the spinal cord. It presents with symptoms related to cranial nerve involvement such as dysphagia, dysarthria, and facial pain. The patient's symptoms and imaging findings are more consistent with syringomyelia, not syringobulbia

 

Educational Objective:

 

Syringomyelia presents with a loss of pain and temperature sensation while preserving touch sensation, and is characterized by cavitation around the central canal of the spinal cord.

questions.text: Drug resistance is seen in which of the following STDs:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gonorrhea

 

Gonorrhea, caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, has exhibited significant drug resistance over the years. Initially, penicillin was the treatment of choice for gonorrhea. However, the emergence of penicillin-resistant strains necessitated a shift to other antibiotics. Fluoroquinolones were subsequently used, but resistance to these agents also developed. Currently, third-generation cephalosporins, such as ceftriaxone, are the recommended treatment. The issue of antibiotic resistance in Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a major public health concern, and ongoing surveillance and development of new treatments are crucial.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syphilis: Syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, has not shown significant drug resistance. It remains highly sensitive to penicillin, which is still the first-line treatment for all stages of syphilis.

 

Option B. Chancroid: Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, has not shown widespread drug resistance. It is typically treated with azithromycin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, or erythromycin.

 

Option C. Donovanosis: Donovanosis, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, is treated with antibiotics such as azithromycin, doxycycline, ciprofloxacin, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Drug resistance is not a significant issue with donovanosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the causative agent of gonorrhea, has developed resistance to multiple antibiotics, including penicillin and fluoroquinolones, making third-generation cephalosporins the current treatment of choice.

questions.text: Double bleb sign seen in early pregnancy is due to? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Yolk sac and amniotic sac

 

Explanation:

 

The double bleb sign is due to the yolk sac and amniotic sac.

 

On USG, gestational sac contains the yolk sac and amniotic sac which appear as two small bubbles known as the double bleb sign.

 

It is seen at 7.5 â€“ 8 weeks.

 

Do not confuse with Double decidual sign

 

 

Double decidual sign â€“ true gestational sac surrounded by two layers â€“ decidua capsularis and decidua parietalis with fluid collection in between.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Twin pregnancy: This would involve two separate gestational sacs or distinct embryonic structures in a single sac, not the double bleb sign of a single gestational sac.

 

Option B. Amnion and chorion: These are two layers surrounding the embryo, but the double bleb sign specifically refers to the early visualization of the yolk sac and amniotic sac.

 

Option D. Heterotopic pregnancy: Involves simultaneous intrauterine and extrauterine pregnancies. This would not specifically relate to the double bleb sign, which is a normal ultrasound finding in a single intrauterine pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The double bleb sign is a normal ultrasound finding in early pregnancy, showing the presence of both the yolk sac and the amniotic sac within the gestational sac, important for confirming a normal early intrauterine pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not useful for hemoglobin estimation by the colorimetric test?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RBC pipette

 

The RBC pipette, identifiable by its red bead, is primarily used for counting red blood cells in a blood sample. It is not suitable for the colorimetric estimation of hemoglobin, as it is not designed for colorimetric comparisons or for mixing the reagents involved in this method.

 

Other Options:

 

The colorimetric method for hemoglobin estimation, often referred to as Sahli's method, relies on comparing the color intensity of a hemoglobin solution to a standard comparator. The primary steps involve mixing a blood sample with N/10 HCl in a graduated hemoglobin tube, which then undergoes color comparison against a brown glass standard.

 

Key Tools Used in Sahli's Method:

 

Option B. Sahli graduated hemoglobin tube: Used to mix blood with hydrochloric acid and measure the resulting color intensity.

 

Option C. Comparator with brown glass standard: Helps in comparing the color of the hemoglobin solution to determine the concentration.

 

Option D. Hemoglobin pipette: Utilized to accurately measure and transfer the blood sample into the graduated hemoglobin tube.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The RBC pipette is not useful for hemoglobin estimation by the colorimetric (Sahli's) method, as it is designed for cell counting rather than for the preparation and color comparison required in this test.

 

Summary Table:

choices.text: 5 alpha reductase deficiency
17 alpha hydroxylase deficiency
Androgen insensitivity syndrome

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes in with primary amenorrhea and indications of virilization. She displays underdeveloped breasts and pubic hair consistent with prepubertal stages, rated at Tanner stage 2. She has a closed-off vaginal canal and noticeable enlargement of the clitoris. Despite her female sex, her testosterone levels are within the male range. Her genetic makeup is 46XY. What is the likely medical diagnosis in this case? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5 alpha reductase deficiency

 

Explanation:

 

The given scenario points to a diagnosis of 5 alpha reductase deficiency.

 

5 alpha reductase deficiency causes inability to convert testosterone to DHT.

 

When DHT levels are low, newborns will possess external genitalia with a feminine appearance. These youngsters are commonly brought up as girls until they reach puberty, at which point they begin to display signs of masculinization due to the influence of testosterone. As a result, clitoromegaly becomes evident. The absence of estrogen conversion from testosterone results in limited breast growth. Scanty pubic hair is observed since its growth is contingent on both testosterone and dihydrotestosterone.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 17 alpha hydroxylase deficiency: Leads to reduced formation of corticosteroids, sex hormones and increased mineralocorticoids (causing hypokalemia and hypertension). Patient with XY chromosome presents with atypical genitalia and undescended testes. Patient with XX chromosome lacks secondary sexual development.

 

Option C. Androgen insensitivity syndrome: Defect in androgen receptor resulting in female-appearing genetic male (46, XY); female external genitalia with scant axillary and pubic hair, rudimentary vagina; uterus and fallopian tubes absent due to persistence of anti-Mullerian hormone from testes. Patients develop normal functioning testes. Patient has increased testosterone, estrogen & LH as compared to other sex chromosome disorders.

 

Option D. Swyer syndrome: 46 XY gonadal dysgenesis; Absent secondary sexual characters, but normal female internal and external genitalia. Gonadectomy needs to be done.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5-alpha reductase deficiency causes primary amenorrhea and virilization in genetic females (46XY), resulting in the inability to convert testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT). This leads to female external genitalia at birth and masculinization at puberty, with signs such as clitoromegaly and underdeveloped breasts.

questions.text: Which of the following methods uses RNA? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) RT-PCR

 

  • RT-PCR is a molecular biology technique used to amplify and analyze RNA.
  • It involves the conversion of RNA into complementary DNA (cDNA) using reverse transcription, followed by PCR amplification of the cDNA.
  • RT-PCR is specifically used for RNA analysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Western blot:

  • Western blotting is a technique used to detect and analyze proteins.
  • It involves the separation of proteins by gel electrophoresis and their subsequent transfer to a membrane for detection using antibodies specific to the protein of interest.
  • Western blotting primarily deals with proteins, not RNA.

 

Option C. Sanger's method (Sanger Sequencing):

  • Sanger sequencing is a DNA sequencing technique developed by Frederick Sanger.
  • It is used to determine the nucleotide sequence of DNA strands.
  • Sanger sequencing deals with DNA, not RNA.

 

Option D. G-banding:

  • G-banding is a cytogenetic staining technique used to visualize and analyze the banding patterns of chromosomes.
  • It is used in karyotyping and primarily focuses on the visualization of chromosomal DNA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RT-PCR is a method for detection of gene expression using reverse transcription of RNA to synthesize cDNA. Western Blot most commonly involve antigen-antibody interactions which is a.protein-protein interaction. Sangerâ€™s method is a DNA sequencing technique by chain termination of DNA polymerization using DNA as template. G-banding is a chromosomal staining technique usually done for karyotyping analysis and involve only DNA.

 

Ref- Lehninger 6th e/p 331

questions.text: To which organism does the provided image of the cell wall belong? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria meningitides

 

  • The displayed picture illustrates a cell wall of a gram negative bacteria
  • It shows presence of  lipooligosaccharides (LOS), which strongly indicates the presence of Neisseria meningitidis.
  • Unlike lipopolysaccharide (LPS), LOS lacks a lengthy 0-antigen side chain.
  • This unique characteristic makes it a significant virulence factor, observed in only a limited number of organisms, including N. gonorrhoeae, N. meningitidis, H. ducreyi, and others.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive bacterium and does not have a cell wall structure similar to the one depicted.

 

Option B. Escherichia coli is a gram-negative bacterium, but it has LPS instead of LOS.

 

Option D. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative bacterium, but it has LPS rather than LOS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria meningitidis is identified by the presence of lipooligosaccharides (LOS) in its cell wall, a distinguishing feature of this gram-negative bacterium.

questions.text: A patient presented with sinusitis, ulcerative lesions on the nasopharynx, nodular lesions with cavitations of the lung, and renal failure. Which of the following is the most useful investigation in this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Test for ANCA


The clinical presentation of ENT involvement, lung nodules with cavitations, and renal failure suggests granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA). The ANCA (anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies) test is a useful diagnostic tool for GPA.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Biopsy to show granulomas is useful but more invasive.

 

Option C. AFB staining of sputum is for TB, not GPA.

 

Option D. BAL (bronchoalveolar lavage):  is not specific for diagnosing GPA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In suspected GPA, the ANCA test is the most useful initial investigation.

choices.text: Visible peristalsis from left to right

questions.text: A child is diagnosed with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, which among the following will not be seen in this child? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bilious vomiting

 

In congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, the hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pylorus muscle lead to gastric outlet obstruction. This causes projectile, non-bilious vomiting because the obstruction is proximal to the bile duct entry into the duodenum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Visible peristalsis from left to right: Due to the obstruction caused by CHPS, there's an increase in gastric peristalsis as the stomach tries to push its contents past the hypertrophied pylorus. This can result in visible waves of peristalsis moving from the left side of the abdomen (where the stomach is located) to the right side (towards the pylorus) on giving a feed.

 

Option C. Hypochloremia and hypokalemia: Persistent vomiting in CHPS can lead to the loss of gastric acid (hydrochloric acid). This results in hypochloremia due to the loss of chloride ions. The body also tries to compensate for the alkalosis by excreting more potassium in the kidneys, leading to hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis: As mentioned earlier, the loss of gastric acid from repeated vomiting results in a state of metabolic alkalosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CHPS (congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis) is most commonly seen in infants between 2 to 8 weeks of age.
  • It is caused by the hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the Pylorus, which results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet.
  • First-born male infants are at the highest risk for developing CHPS.
  • Projectile, non-bilious vomiting is a common symptom in infants with CHPS.
  • A palpable olive-shaped mass is usually felt in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium, and visible peristalsis can be observed moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting.
  • Infants with CHPS develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality including hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.
  • Loss of hydrochloric acid leads to metabolic alkalosis and hypochloremia due to persistent vomiting.
  • The kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3, but the loss of sodium stimulates aldosterone secretion leading to the loss of potassium ions (hypokalemia).
  • Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in paradoxical aciduria.
  • Treatment involves rehydration and correction of metabolic abnormalities before surgery, and the Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard surgical procedure for CHPS.

questions.text: In spine straightening surgeries, screws used for fixation are inserted through which of the following parts of the vertebra? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pedicle

 

  • Spinal instrumentation (rods,  screws, hooks, etc.) are applied to the region of the spine to be corrected through transpedicular route and bone graft is added. 

  • In the spine straightening surgery, to stabilize the spine, screws are placed on the pedicles of the vertebral bone. 

 

 

  • Hooks may also be used in conjunction with screws, and are placed around the pedicle or around the lamina.

  • Rods are then secured in the screw heads, connecting adjacent vertebrae. 

  • The rods are shaped to match the desired corrected curvature of the spine, and are attached to the screws and/or hooks.

  • Bone graft material is placed around the final assembly and as the spine heals, spinal fusion is accomplished by bone growth between the vertebrae. This bone growth permanently fixes the spine in the desired position. The implants hold the spine in the corrected position while the spine fuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pedicle of the vertebra is the area used to fixate the screws through during the spine straightening surgeries for scoliosis.

questions.text: Jackson Rees circuit is used in: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pediatric controlled ventilation

 

Jackson Rees circuit (also known as Mapleson F circuit) is specifically designed for:

 

  • Pediatric patients
  • Can be used for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation in children
  • It's a modification of the Ayre's T-piece with an open-ended bag
  • This circuit is ideal for pediatric anesthesia due to its low resistance and minimal dead space

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Adult controlled ventilation: Not appropriate as Jackson Rees circuit is designed for pediatric patients. Adults require circuits with larger volumes and different configurations.

 

Option C. Obstetric ventilation: Obstetric patients require specialized circuits that can deliver high flow rates and manage rapid changes in ventilation demands.

 

Option D. Cardiac patients: Cardiac patients typically require precise control over ventilation parameters, which is better achieved with more sophisticated circuits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Jackson Rees circuit (Mapleson F) is specifically designed and used for pediatric anesthesia, suitable for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation.

choices.text: Decreases risk of Colon cancer
Decreased risk of breast cancer
Decreased risk of endometrial cancer
Increases risk of osteoporosis

questions.text: Which of the following is a true association related to HRT (Hormone replacement therapy) among the options provided? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreases risk of Colon cancer

 

Explanation:

 

Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) has been associated with a decreased risk of colon cancer. Studies have shown that estrogen in HRT may have a protective effect against the development of colon cancer. This effect is believed to be related to estrogen’s impact on gastrointestinal mucosal growth and repair.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Decreased risk of breast cancer: This option is incorrect. HRT, particularly with estrogen and progestin, is associated with an increased risk of breast cancer. Long-term use of combined HRT has been shown to elevate the risk of breast cancer in several studies.

 

Option C. Decreased risk of endometrial cancer: This option is incorrect. Unopposed estrogen (estrogen alone without progestin) increases the risk of endometrial cancer. To mitigate this risk, progestin is often added to HRT in women with an intact uterus.

 

Option D. Increases risk of osteoporosis: This option is incorrect. HRT is actually used prophylactically to reduce the risk of osteoporosis. Estrogen helps maintain bone density and prevent bone loss, which is beneficial in managing osteoporosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) decreases the risk of colon cancer.

questions.text: The vector shown in the image below transmits which of the following organism? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Orientia tsutsugamushi

 

  • The picture depicts a trombiculid mite, known for transmitting Orientia tsutsugamushi.

 

SCRUB TYPHUS (ORIENTIA)

 

  • Caused by â†’ Orientia tsutsugamushi
  • Vector â†’ Trombiculid mites (Leptotrombidium)
  • Chiggerosis â†’ Among all stages of mite, larvae (called chiggers) are only stage that feed on humans. Hence, scrub typhus is also called chiggerosis.
  • Clinical manifestations
    • Eschar (at the site of bite)
    • Regional lymphadenopathy
    • Maculopapular rash
  • DOC â†’ Doxycycline

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kyasanur forest disease: Kyasanur forest disease is vector borne disease caused by hard tick.

 

 

Option C. Chandipura virus: Chandipura virus is vector borne disease transmitted by sandfly

 

 

Option D. Anaplasma: Anaplasma is a tick-borne disease affecting ruminants, dogs, and horses, and is caused by Anaplasma bacteria. Mainly transmitted by Ixodes ticks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The trombiculid mite, particularly in its larval stage called a chigger, transmits Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus.

choices.text: N - hydroxy cyclophosphamide
4 - hydroxy cyclophosphamide
4 - acetyl cyclophosphamide
N - acetyl cyclophosphamide

questions.text: The active metabolite of cyclophosphamide is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 4 - hydroxy cyclophosphamide

 

  • Cyclophosphamide is an alkylating chemotherapeutic agent whose active metabolite is 4-hydroxy cyclophosphamide.
  • Side Effects:
    • Hemorrhagic Cystitis: One of the most notable side effects of cyclophosphamide is hemorrhagic cystitis. This is due to the accumulation of the metabolite acrolein in the bladder. To prevent this, mesna (a uroprotective agent) is administered alongside cyclophosphamide, and patients are advised to maintain adequate hydration.
    • Pulmonary Fibrosis: Another significant side effect is pulmonary fibrosis, which can affect lung function.
    • Bone Marrow Suppression: Like many chemotherapeutic agents, cyclophosphamide can also cause bone marrow suppression, leading to leukopenia, anemia, and thrombocytopenia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyclophosphamide's therapeutic effects are primarily due to its active metabolite, 4-hydroxy cyclophosphamide. It is important to manage the side effects of cyclophosphamide, particularly hemorrhagic cystitis, through the use of mesna and adequate hydration. Pulmonary fibrosis and bone marrow suppression are other significant side effects to be monitored during treatment.

questions.text:
Under which circumstances is live vaccination not contraindicated? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. DiGeorge syndrome
  2. Wiskott Aldrich Syndrome
  3. Ataxia telangiectasia
  4. Complement deficiency
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4 only

 

Live vaccinations are generally contraindicated in individuals with certain immunodeficiency disorders because their immune systems may not be able to handle the attenuated (weakened) pathogens in the vaccines, potentially leading to severe infections. However, there are exceptions based on the nature of the immunodeficiency.

 

  • Complement deficiency: This is a condition where components of the complement system (a part of the immune system) are deficient. Complement deficiencies do not affect the cellular immune response significantly, meaning that the risk of adverse effects from live vaccinations is not increased. Therefore, individuals with complement deficiency can receive live vaccines safely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. DiGeorge syndrome: DiGeorge syndrome involves a defect in T-cell production due to thymic hypoplasia. Since T-cells are crucial for mounting an immune response to vaccines, live vaccines are contraindicated.

 

Option C. Ataxia telangiectasia: This is a condition characterized by defects in both the immune system and DNA repair mechanisms. Patients with this condition have a higher risk of developing severe infections from live vaccines, so they are contraindicated.

 

Option D. Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome: This is an X-linked recessive disorder affecting both the immune system and platelet production. Individuals with Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome are at risk for severe infections from live vaccines due to their compromised immune function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Complement deficiency does not pose a contraindication for live vaccination.

 

However, it is important to note that live vaccines should be avoided in individuals with DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome, and Ataxia telangiectasia, because these are immunodeficiency disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following does not have polysaccharide vaccine?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hepatitis B

 

Polysaccharide vaccines are typically made from the polysaccharide capsule that surrounds certain bacteria. These vaccines are designed to protect against bacterial infections by inducing immunity against the polysaccharide antigens present in the capsule.

 

Hepatitis B vaccine is not a polysaccharide vaccine. It is a recombinant vaccine that uses a portion of the hepatitis B virus (HBsAg - hepatitis B surface antigen) produced in yeast cells. This vaccine does not involve a polysaccharide component as the hepatitis B virus does not have a polysaccharide capsule.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumococcal: The pneumococcal vaccine is available in both polysaccharide (PPSV23) and conjugate forms (PCV13), targeting the polysaccharide capsule of Streptococcus pneumoniae.

 

Option B. Meningococcal: Meningococcal vaccines also include polysaccharide (MPSV4) and conjugate forms (MCV4), aimed at the polysaccharide capsule of Neisseria meningitidis.

 

Option C. H. influenzae: The Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) vaccine is a conjugate vaccine that includes the polysaccharide antigen from the bacterial capsule conjugated to a protein carrier.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant vaccine, not a polysaccharide vaccine, as it targets a virus that does not have a polysaccharide capsule.

questions.text: Identify this instrument used in laparoscopic surgery? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Veress needle

 

The Veress needle is an instrument displayed in the image that is utilized to inflate the abdomen for laparoscopic surgery. In laparoscopic procedures, there are two ways of establishing abdominal access: the direct puncture technique (closed technique) and the open technique. The Veress needle is specifically used in the direct puncture laparoscopy method.

 

Lind's Needle: Lind's needle is a type of trocar and cannula system used in medical procedures, particularly for draining fluids or inserting catheters. It consists of a sharp, pointed needle (the trocar) that is enclosed within a cannula.

choices.text: Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to right ear
Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to left ear
Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to right ear
Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to left ear

questions.text:
A woman presents with impaired hearing. Her audiometry findings are given below:  (INICET Nov 2021)

 

 

Pick the right combination of tuning fork test results that would be seen in this patient. (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Left Rinneâ€™s test positive, Weberâ€™s test lateralized to right ear

 

Based on the provided tympanogram findings, it is likely that the tuning fork tests for this patient would reveal a positive left Rinne test and Weber test lateralized to the right ear (normal ear).

 

 

INTERPRETATION OF AUDIOGRAM

 

  • Whenever a PTA is given, first see whether there is air-bone gap (AC & BC curves are separated by a long gap) or not
  • If there is no air-bone gap or very little gap, then it could be sensorineural hearing loss.
  • If there is a long separation in between the AC & BC curves, then it could be either conductive or mixed.
  • First see whether the distantly separated curves are present in the upper part of the graph or lower part.
  • If occupying upper part, then it is conductive hearing loss and if occupying lower part, then it could be mixed.
  • In the question given above, left sided air conduction and bone conduction curves do not have any gap and they are occupying middle part of the graph. Hence, it is left SNHL.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to right ear: This result would be expected in conductive hearing loss, not SNHL.

 

Option B. Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to left ear: This also indicates conductive hearing loss, which is not supported by the audiogram findings.

 

Option D. Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to left ear: This would indicate normal hearing or mild hearing loss in the right ear, which does not match the audiogram showing significant SNHL in the left ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In sensorineural hearing loss, Rinne's test remains positive, and Weber's test lateralizes to the better-hearing ear. The provided audiogram indicates left-sided SNHL, resulting in a positive Rinne test on the left and Weber lateralizing to the right ear.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 24, 25

questions.text:
Which among the following statements is true regarding the course of the mandibular nerve? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Auriculotemporal nerve is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it emerges from behind the temporomandibular joint.
  2. Buccal branch is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it emerges from behind the mandibular ramus.
  3. Lingual nerve is a branch from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it arcs around the submandibular duct.
  4. Ophthalmic nerve is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it arises in the middle cranial fossa.
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 2,3

 

Explanation:

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 2: True. The buccal branch, which is indeed a branch of the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, emerges from behind the mandibular ramus. This nerve primarily supplies sensory innervation to the skin over the cheek and buccal mucosa.

 

Statement 3: True. The lingual nerve, a branch from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, is responsible for providing sensory innervation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It famously arcs around the submandibular duct, a notable anatomical feature.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 1: Incorrect. The auriculotemporal nerve actually arises from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, not the anterior division, and it does indeed emerge from behind the temporomandibular joint.

 

Statement 4: Incorrect. The ophthalmic nerve is not a branch of the mandibular nerve. Instead, it is an independent division of the trigeminal nerve (V1), originating from the trigeminal ganglion located in the middle cranial fossa. It is responsible for providing sensory innervation to the forehead, scalp, and parts of the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mandibular nerve's complex branching includes both sensory and motor components that are essential for facial sensation and movements. Understanding its branches, such as the buccal and lingual nerves, and their courses, is critical in dental, surgical, and diagnostic practices.

choices.text: It is the body's response to anything that requires attention or action causing physical, emotional, or psychological strain

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate definition of stress? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is the body's response to anything that requires attention or action causing physical, emotional, or psychological strain.

 

Stress is a broad term that encompasses the body's physical, emotional, and psychological responses to any demand or threat, whether real or perceived.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. External stress: It is inaccurate as not all stress arises from external pressure. Personal thoughts, emotions, and internal conflicts can also induce stress.

 

Option B. Muscle tension: It simplifies stress to just "mental tension." While mental tension can be a component of stress, the definition doesn't capture the breadth of physiological and psychological reactions associated with stress.

 

Option D. Internal strain: It refers to the outcome of the stress rather than the cause or process of stress itself.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Stress can be conceptualized as the body's adaptive response to demands or threats. It's not just a psychological phenomenon; it has physiological correlates as well. Stressors can be external (e.g., environmental pressures) or internal (e.g., illness, or undergoing a medical procedure), and they can be short-lived (acute) or long-term (chronic).

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadockâ€™s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 2117

questions.text: Calculate for Burn Surface Area (BSA) for a patent with burn involving the chest and abdomen right arm and right thigh (circumferental): (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 31.5% 

 

According to the â€˜Rule of Nineâ€™, BSA is calculated as: 

 

  • Chest and Abdomen = 18%
  • Right Arm (not entire upper limb) = 4.5%
  • Right Thigh = 9%

 

Total = 18% + 4.5% + 9% = 31.5%

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Rule of Nines is a method used to estimate the total body surface area affected by burns. It divides the body into sections that represent approximately 9% of the total surface area, facilitating quick and effective assessment and treatment planning for burn patients.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the given image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic osteomyelitis

 

The provided CT scan image shows significant periosteal thickening and sclerosis within the diaphysis of the bone, accompanied by central lucency. These radiological features are characteristic of chronic osteomyelitis. Chronic osteomyelitis is a long-standing infection of the bone, leading to extensive periosteal reaction, sclerosis, and central areas of bone destruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ewing sarcoma: Typically presents with a large soft tissue mass and periosteal reaction. The symmetrical soft tissue in the image makes this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma: Usually arises in the metaphysis, with characteristic sunburst periosteal reaction and periosteal lifting, not observed in this diaphyseal lesion.

 

Option D. Fracture: Would present with a distinct fracture line, which is not visible in the image provided. The periosteal reaction and sclerosis are also not typical for a simple fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic osteomyelitis is characterized by periosteal thickening, sclerosis, and central lucency within the bone, which are key diagnostic features visible on imaging.

questions.text: Wobble hypothesis is due to which property of the codon?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Degeneracy

 

  • The wobble hypothesis is primarily due to the degeneracy of the genetic code. Degeneracy means that multiple codons can code for the same amino acid. The third position of the codon (the wobble position) is less constrained and allows for some variation in the base pairing, which accommodates the degeneracy in the genetic code.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ambiguity: Ambiguity is not a property of the codon but rather a state of uncertainty or multiple interpretations. In the genetic code, codons are specific and not ambiguous in their assignment to amino acids.

 

Option C. Universality: Universality refers to the fact that the genetic code is nearly identical in all living organisms. While universality is an important property of the genetic code, it is not directly related to the wobble hypothesis.

 

Option D. Commaless: "Commaless" is not a recognized property related to the codon or the wobble hypothesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The wobble hypothesis is primarily due to the degeneracy of the genetic code, allowing multiple codons to code for the same amino acid, with variation in the third (wobble) position of the codon.

 

Wobble bases

 

3rd base of the codon on mRNA and 1st base of anticodon on tRNA in 5â€™ to 3â€™ direction are wobble positions.

 

 

Wobble hypothesis says that for binding between bases present in these positions, some imprecision is allowed. i.e. one base in anticodon can bind with various bases of codon. This is also called as degeneracy of codon i.e. There is more than one codon for one amino acid. So, Wobble hypothesis is due to degeneracy of codons.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of inherited Thrombophilia? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Factor V Leiden mutation

 

Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of thrombophilia. This genetic mutation makes Factor V resistant to inactivation by activated Protein C, leading to increased thrombotic risk. It is an autosomal dominant disorder and is particularly common in individuals of European descent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protein C deficiency: Less common than Factor V Leiden; leads to increased thrombotic risk

 

Option B. Prothrombin deficiency: A rare inherited coagulation disorder that typically causes bleeding

 

Option D. Antithrombin III deficiency: Relatively rare inherited thrombophilic condition

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of thrombophilia.

choices.text: Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus association is high
Association with mucocutaneous candidiasis is high

questions.text: Which of the following is not typically associated with Autoimmune Polyendocrine Syndrome Type 1 (APS-1)? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus association is high

 

Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus does not have a high association with APS-1. The association is low and not a characteristic feature of APS-1.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypoparathyroidism is common: Hypoparathyroidism is common and is part of the classic triad of APS-1.

 

Option C. Association with mucocutaneous candidiasis is high: Mucocutaneous candidiasis is highly associated with APS-1. It is typically the first manifestation, appearing in infancy, and is also the most common manifestation due to underlying immunodeficiency.

 

Option D. Early onset in infancy: Early onset in infancy is characteristic of APS-1, with mucocutaneous candidiasis typically being the first manifestation to appear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classic triad of APS-1:

 

  1. Mucocutaneous candidiasis (most common and earliest manifestation)
  2. Hypoparathyroidism
  3. Addison's disease

questions.text: Which of the following triad is seen after an acute attack of angle-closure glaucoma? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vogt's triad

 

  • Vogt's triad is seen after an acute attack of primary angle-closure glaucoma.
  • It includes glaukomflecken, patches of iris atrophy, and a slightly dilated nonreactive pupil.
  • Glaukomflecken is used to describe an anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity due to necrosis of lens cortical fibers.
  • The mid-dilated pupil is attributed to sphincter atrophy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Virchow triad is used to describe the abnormalities that result in thrombosis. It includes endothelial injury, abnormal blood flow, and hypercoagulability of the blood.

 

Option C. Hutchinson triad is used to describe manifestations of congenital syphilis. It includes interstitial keratitis, Hutchinson teeth, and eighth nerve deafness. Hutchinson teeth are screw-driver or peg shaped small incisors.

 

Option D. Gaucher's triad is not a named triad. Hypertonia, strabismus, and stridor usually point to a diagnosis of type 2 Gaucher's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vogt's triad in a patient with a history of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma can aid in rapid diagnosis and management of this potentially vision-threatening condition. It underscores the importance of timely intervention to preserve ocular health and prevent irreversible complications.

choices.text: Elevated levels of gamma glutamyl transpeptidas

questions.text: All of the following side effects are more commonly seen with carbamazepine than oxcarbazepine, except: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hyponatremia

 

  • Hyponatremia is more commonly observed in individuals taking oxcarbazepine compared to those taking carbamazepine.
  • Both of these antiepileptic drugs can contribute to hyponatremia by enhancing the effects of ADH (antidiuretic hormone), leading to increased retention of water, which in turn reduces the osmolarity and causes hyponatremia. However, the incidence of hyponatremia appears to be higher with oxcarbazepine when compared to carbamazepine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypotension: Hypotension is more commonly seen with carbamazepine. It can affect cardiovascular function and lead to decreased blood pressure.

 

Option C. Rash: Rash is a common side effect of both drugs, but it is more frequently seen with carbamazepine. Skin reactions can range from mild to severe, including Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis.

 

Option D. Elevated levels of gamma glutamyl transpeptidases (GGT): Elevated GGT levels are more commonly associated with carbamazepine use. GGT is an enzyme found in the liver, and its elevated levels can indicate liver enzyme induction or liver injury, which is more common with carbamazepine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyponatremia is more commonly associated with oxcarbazepine than carbamazepine. While both drugs can cause similar side effects due to their similar mechanisms of action, certain adverse effects, such as hypotension, rash, and elevated GGT levels, are more frequently seen with carbamazepine.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man from Mumbai presents to a clinic with fatigue and weakness. His family has a history of chronic diseases, but he himself has been asymptomatic until recently. The physician explains the different stages of disease progression and the interventions required. Which of the following best matches the stages with their relevant descriptions? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 1-d, 2-b, 3-a, 4-c

 

  • Natural history of disease refers to the progression of a disease in an individual over time, in the absence of treatment. It has two phases, a period of pre-pathogenesis and a period of pathogenesis.

 

 

  • The period of pre-pathogenesis is before the onset of disease in humans.
  • An interaction between the agent, host and the environment occurs in this phase before the pathogenesis.
  • It starts with appropriate exposure to or accumulation of factors sufficient for the disease process to begin in a susceptible host.
  • The exposure is a microorganism in an infectious disease. For lung cancer, it is any factor that initiates the process, such as asbestos fibres or components in tobacco smoke.
  • Primary prevention (health promotion and specific protection) is applicable in this period.
  • The period of pathogenesis starts after the disease process has been triggered and pathological changes occur without the individual being aware of it.
  • It begins with the entry of the organism till recovery, death, or disability.
