  • The subclinical or asymptomatic period between exposure and onset of symptoms is called the incubation period for infectious diseases, and the latency period for chronic diseases.
  • The onset of clinical symptoms is the beginning of the clinical stage of the disease.
  • Secondary (halting of the disease process) and tertiary prevention (measures to limit disability) are applicable in this period.
  • Rehabilitation has been defined as the use of medical, social, educational, and vocational measures for training the individual to the highest possible level of functional ability.
  • It is a part of tertiary prevention like providing callipers for walking patients and arranging schooling after being affected by polio.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The Thymus gland is specialized in identifying the molecules of the Major Histocompatibility Complex that are presented to it. It discerns whether these cells belong to the body's own or are of foreign origin. Which specific gene is accountable for this function? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) AIRE

 

Autoimmunity refers to immune reactions against self-antigens. Normal persons are unresponsive (tolerant) to their own (self) antigens, and autoimmunity results from a failure of self-tolerance.

 

Self-tolerance involves two broad mechanisms: Central Tolerance and Peripheral Tolerance.

 

AIRE (Autoimmune regulator) stimulates expression of some peripheral tissue-restricted self-antigens in the thymus and is critical for deletion of immature T cells specific for these self-antigens. Mutations in the AIRE gene are the cause of an autoimmune polyendocrinopathy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. NOTCH1: NOTCH1 plays a role in cell growth and division (proliferation), maturation (differentiation), and self-destruction (apoptosis).

 

Option B. E2A: E2A proteins function by recruiting proteins that drive epigenetic remodeling that precedes transcription.

 

Option C. Rag ½: Recombination-activating genes RAG 1 and RAG 2 initiate the molecular processes that lead to lymphocyte receptor formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The AIRE gene is crucial for promoting self-tolerance by ensuring that developing T cells in the thymus are exposed to self-antigens, thus preventing autoimmune diseases.

choices.text: Nicotine gum

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective drug in smoking cessation?(INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Varenicline

 

Varenicline is the most effective drug in smoking cessation. Varenicline is a partial agonist at the α4β2 nicotinic receptors. It is one of the 1st line oral drugs that is used for smoking cessation. The other drugs are Bupropion, even Nicotine replacement in the form of gums, lozenge, patch, spray can also be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Buspirone: Primarily used for the treatment of anxiety disorders, buspirone is not used for smoking cessation. Bupropion is used for smoking cessation.

 

Option C. Nicotine gum: As a form of nicotine replacement therapy (NRT), nicotine gum helps to reduce withdrawal symptoms and cravings by supplying a small amount of nicotine. While effective for many people, it may be less effective than prescription medications like varenicline, especially for heavy smokers.

 

Option D. Rimonabant: This drug was initially developed as an anti-obesity medication and was found to also have some effect on smoking cessation. However, it was withdrawn from the market due to psychiatric side effects, including depression and suicidal thoughts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Varenicline is the most effective medication for smoking cessation. It works as a partial agonist at nicotinic receptors, helping to alleviate withdrawal symptoms and reduce the rewarding effects of nicotine. This makes it a highly effective option for individuals seeking to quit smoking.

questions.text: Identify the fracture site in the X-ray shown below. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4th, 5th, 6th rib

 

The given X-ray shows the fracture of the 4th, 5th, 6th rib.

 

 

Tricks to counting ribs:

 

  • The horizontal oriented ribs are posterior ribs
  • The oblique oriented ribs are anterior ribs
  • Count below from 1st rib one after another

 

Counting ribs on a chest X-ray in the posteroanterior (PA) view can be done by locating the clavicle and 1st rib. Count downward from the first rib as you move along.

 

 

Differentiating between posterior and anterior ribs on an X-ray can be done by looking at direction of the Rib Curvature. On a posterior-anterior (PA) chest X-ray, anterior ribs typically exhibit a downward convex curvature as they wrap around the chest wall. In contrast, the posterior ribs have an upward concave curvature as they extend posteriorly towards the spine.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

When identifying rib fractures on a chest X-ray, start counting from the first rib, which is located just beneath the clavicle, and follow downward. Note the curvature of the ribs: anterior ribs curve downward and outward, while posterior ribs curve upward. This method helps in accurately locating and identifying the specific ribs involved in fractures or other abnormalities.
